senses.de: An arrival or entry of large numbers of people or things.
senses.ex: There was an influx of tourists in town due to the festival.

Tips.title: Cultural Peak Seasons
Tips.description: Used to describe times when places experience high volumes of visitors, often due to special events or seasons.
Tips.example: The city experiences a significant influx of tourists during the summer music festival.

Tips.title: Positive or Negative
Tips.description: 'Influx' can indicate either a beneficial or overwhelming scenario, depending on the situation.
Tips.example: The small town struggled to support the sudden influx of visitors.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Use
Tips.description: Can be used metaphorically to describe a surge of non-physical things, like ideas or information.
Tips.example: There's been an influx of new technologies in the past decade.

senses.ex: There is an influx of energy into the system.

Tips.title: Technical Context
Tips.description: Primarily used in scientific or technical discussions to describe movements into a system or area.
Tips.example: The machine was designed to manage the influx of electrical current during power surges.

Tips.title: Energy and Resources
Tips.description: In contexts like physics, it often relates to energy, resources, or substances entering a system.
Tips.example: To maintain balance, the influx of heat must be equal to the outflow.

senses.de: The arrival of a large number of species in a new area.
senses.ex: The island saw an influx of new species after the hurricane.

Tips.title: Ecology Movements
Tips.description: Describes the movement of species into new habitats, which can have significant ecological impacts.
Tips.example: An influx of invasive species can disrupt local ecosystems.

Tips.title: After Environmental Events
Tips.description: Used in ecology to talk about species movement after events like natural disasters or climate changes.
Tips.example: Post-flood, there was an influx of freshwater fish into the estuaries.

Arrival.wordDefinition:
Arrival refers to the act of reaching a destination or a place. It usually refers to one or a few people or things. For example, the arrival of a plane or the arrival of a guest.

Influx is a sudden or large arrival of people, animals or things. It generally refers to a mass of individuals or things.

So, we can say that arrival is applicable in situations where a small number of people or things reach a particular destination, whereas influx is used to indicate a large number of people, animals or things arriving at once.

Entrance.wordDefinition:
Both entrance and influx refer to the idea of things coming in, but they are used in slightly different contexts.

Entrance generally refers to the act of entering or the physical place where you enter something. For example, you might use the word entrance when referring to the entryway of a building, as in "come in through the entrance".

It can also be used more abstractly, to refer to a sense of being captivated or enchanted by something, as in "the music has a very powerful entrance".

Entrance is more commonly used to refer to the act of entering or the physical place where you enter something, while influx describes a sudden and large increase in the amount or number of things coming in.

Entry.wordDefinition:
Entry refers to the act of entering or the point of entry into a place or organization. It is applicable in situations where someone or something is gaining access to a place, such as a person entering a building or a country.

Entry relates to an individual or singular entity gaining access to a place, while influx describes a sudden increase in the number of people or things entering a place.

Incursion.wordDefinition:
Incursion refers to a sudden and brief invasion or attack into a place or territory.

It is often used to describe military or hostile activities. For example, if a neighboring country sends troops into another country's territory, it would be considered an incursion.

Incursion refers more to an attack or invasion, while influx refers to a large increase in people or things.

Inflow.wordDefinition:
Inflow and influx both refer to the movement or arrival of something.

However, inflow usually refers to a steady or continuous flow of something into a place, whereas influx refers to a sudden and large amount of something entering a place.

For example, water flowing into a bathtub from a faucet is an inflow, while a sudden rush of people coming into a store during a sale is an influx.

Inflow is used more for things that are expected or planned, while influx is used more for unexpected or sudden things.

Inundation.wordDefinition:
Inundation refers to an overwhelming amount of something that comes all at once, often causing damage or disruption. For example, an inundation of floodwater that damages homes and crops.

So, basically, influx is used when referring to a sudden increase, while inundation is used when referring to an overwhelming amount that causes damage or disruption.

Invasion.wordDefinition:
Invasion refers to a forceful or aggressive entry into a place or area, often with the intention of taking control.

This is often associated with military conquest or invasion by a foreign country.

An influx refers to a large amount of people or things coming into a place, while an invasion refers to a forceful entry into a place with the intention of taking control.

Migrate.wordDefinition:
Migrate means to move from one place to another, usually with the intention of settling there. It refers to a more long-term and planned movement of people or animals.

For example, birds migrate from one region to another with changing seasons, humans migrate to other countries in search of better job opportunities or better living standards.

An influx refers to a sudden increase or arrival of something, while migration refers to a planned and more permanent move from one place to another.

quotes.Text: The influx of women into paid work and her increased power raise a woman's aspirations and hopes for equal treatment at home. Her lower wage and status at work and the threat of divorce reduce what she presses for and actually expects.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Arlie Russell Hochschild

quotes.Text: The constant influx of new cultures, new ideas and new ways of looking at old problems is a big part of the reason why America has been the most dynamic economy in the world for well over a century.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Gary Locke

quotes.Text: Not that I was not getting offers, the big banners might not come but there was still an influx of offers but you know, my growth as an actor was stagnant. I did not want to do the same thing.
quotes.Title: Indian Actor
quotes.Name: Rahul Roy

quotes.Text: The ability to identify someone at a moment's notice by snapping a photo of him or her, to trigger an immediate influx of data about the person behind the face, will forever change the world.
quotes.Title: Businessman
quotes.Name: Jan Chipchase

quotes.Text: However, in recent years our nation has seen a sizable influx of illegal immigration that at best highlights some alarming inadequacies and at worst indicates a broken system.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Spencer Bachus

quotes.Text: I want to stop the influx of new immigrants. This way, we can give those who are already here the opportunity to fully integrate into our society.
quotes.Title: Dutch Politician
quotes.Name: Pim Fortuyn

quotes.Text: If you lose your job because there has been an influx of labour from another country, that is a legitimate cause for concern.
quotes.Title: British Politician
quotes.Name: Keir Starmer

quotes.Text: It's hard to say if the NBA is hurt by the influx of younger players, but it's definitely impacted the league.
quotes.Title: American Basketball Player
quotes.Name: Michael Jordan

quotes.Text: In order to keep pace with the influx of work I had to take on fresh hands.
quotes.Title: Scottish Inventor
quotes.Name: James Nasmyth

quotes.Text: The influx of migrants must be stopped.
quotes.Title: French Politician
quotes.Name: Marine Le Pen
